title: Jere D. Gallagher
text:
in memorium
Throughout her career, Dr. Jere Dee Gallagher was highly regarded and esteemed as an authority on child development. She dedicated most of her time to the University of Pittsburgh’s School of Education, where she eventually rose to the position of associate dean. During her tenure, she was instrumental in creating the Kinder Kinetics Program in the Health and Physical Activity Department, which she directed for over 25 years and considered her life’s crowning achievement

title: Furtado-Gallagher Computerized Observational Movement Assessment System
text:
The Children Observational Movement Pattern Assessment System1 (FG-COMPASS) is an assessment tool designed to evaluate the proficiency of fundamental movement skills in children between the ages of 5 to 10. It can be utilized in both educational and clinical environments.
The tool employs a decision-tree strategy to evaluate proficiency levels of skills. The model framework is illustrated below:






Figure 1: Framework model for the decision trees



Where,

DQ is the discriminatory question
UCQ is the upper confirmatory question
LCQ is the lower confirmatory question
Levels 1-4 are the resulting proficiency skill levels

The purpose of DQ is to differentiate between the highest and lowest levels, namely levels 1 and 4. UCQ is designed to verify if an individual is at level 4. If UCQ fails to confirm level 4, then the individual is evaluated as level 3. Similarly, LCQ is meant to confirm if an individual is at level 1. If LCQ fails to confirm level 1, then the individual is evaluated as level 2.
Using the framework mentioned earlier, decision-trees were created for 10 movement skills, which include 5 Locomotor and 5 Manipulative skills. Below is an example of the decision-tree for the Overhand Throw.






Figure 2: Decision tree for Throwing











Level 1





Level 2







Level 3





Level 4








Footnotes


Formally know as “Computerized Observational Movement Pattern Assessment System”.↩︎

title: WebApp
text:
We are excited to announce the release of the WebApp prototype of our innovative assessment tool, FG-COMPASS! This initial release focuses on one of the ten skills that make up our comprehensive assessment framework: Overhand Throwing.
We have been working diligently to develop a web application that offers an intuitive and accurate assessment experience. Today, we are proud to unveil the prototype for Overhand Throwing.
We invite you to test the prototype and provide valuable feedback to help us improve and refine the tool.
To try the FG-COMPASS Overhand Throwing prototype, click the link below.
Thank you for your continued support and interest in the FG-COMPASS.
https://fgcompass.shinyapps.io/throw/

title: Ovande Furtado JR
text:
Dr. Furtado received a B.A. in Physical Education from the Federal University of Parana, Curitiba, PR - Brazil. He earned his M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in Motor Behavior from the University of Pittsburgh, PA. Dr. Furtado’s line of research focuses on two main areas: (1) validation of observational models in psychomotor assessment instruments and (2) the relationship between motor skill competence, perceived motor competence, physical activity levels, and body composition.

Education
Ph.D. in Motor Behavior, 2009 - University of Pittsburgh
M.S. in Motor Behavior, 2004 - University of Pittsburgh
B.A. in Physical Education K-12, 1998 - Federal University of Parana - Brazil


Experience
Associate Professor Cal State Northridge Aug 2013 – Present Northridge, CA Teaches motor behavior and statistics courses.
Associate Professor Eastern Illinois University Aug 2007 – Jun 2013 Charleston, IL Taught motor behavior and statistics courses.
Physical Educator Teacher K-12 Falk Lab School Aug 2006 – Jun 2007 Pittsburgh, PA Taught motor skill development for children K-12.
Kinder Kinetics Movement Program Co-Director University of Pittsburgh Aug 2006 – Jun 2007 Pittsburgh, PA
